image.altText: Matthew Mapley standing in front of his unfinished house.

props.synopsis: When Matthew Mapley questioned why the bank had paid his builder for unfinished works, it said it had his written authority — except he hadn't signed it.

title.children: 'I never signed this': Home owner saw his signature on builder payment

image.altText: Dr Alan Richardson

props.synopsis: Rural generalists are GPs with training in emergency care and one other advanced skill area. While Tasmania has a training program for rural generalists, doctors say their skills are not properly recognised by the Tasmanian Health Service.

title.children: GPs who want to stay in Tasmania say there are no jobs for their skills

image.altText: A man with hiking gear and sunglasses crouches in front of a cliff overlooking a river.

props.synopsis: Rescue crews have faced challenging conditions in the search for Daryl Fong, who has been missing in Tasmania's Mount Field National Park since last Sunday.

title.children: Brother of missing Tasmanian bushwalker thanks crews as search continues

image.altText: A teenage boy pats a fluffy wombat in a grassy area with spots of snow.

props.synopsis: Tom French's agoraphobia meant he couldn't leave the house to access the mental health care he needed, but a Hospital in the Home program means the care is coming to him.

title.children: Tom went from 'nature lover' to agoraphobia, but now he's getting help

image.altText: A graphic of a magnifying glass and a box filled with office supplies. The box has the Tasmanian Government logo on it.

props.synopsis: Seven years after allegations were made against a practitioner who was allegedly misusing public resources, Tasmania's Integrity Commission has finalised its investigation into the matter. However, the report has not been released to the public.

title.children: Tasmania's integrity body finishes 2019 probe but report still secret

image.altText: Young woman with shoulder-length brown hair wearing white hoodie smiles holding handles of a BMX bike

props.synopsis: When Saya Sakakibara saw her brother nearly die in a BMX crash, fear took hold. It nearly broke the star siblings’ Olympic dream.

title.children: Zero to 55kph in two seconds — Saya admits she is terrified of her sport

image.altText: University students in a large crowd outside

props.synopsis: At least a dozen Australian universities are using AI to detect AI. But they're not always catching cheats. Instead, they're wrongly accusing students of academic misconduct.

title.children: AI errors detecting AI a sector-wide problem for Australian unis

image.altText: An app on a smartphone screen

props.synopsis: Speculative manias where the first investors win because there isn't a bust are rare occurrences.

title.children: If AI is a good investment, we're in trouble

image.altText: Barnaby Joyce at anti renewable energy protest

props.synopsis: Nationals MPs do not expect others would follow Barnaby Joyce if he defects to One Nation.

title.children: Nationals do not fear 'contagion' effect if Joyce defects to One Nation

image.altText: A woman standing behind train route lines.

props.synopsis: Over the past few years, daily commutes have changed with flexible work arrangements. Most OECD countries' commute times are about 30 minutes. So how does Australia compare?

title.children: How Australian work commutes compare with other OECD nations

image.altText: Trent Dalton, a man in his mid-40s, in glasses and blazer, stands smiling outside a suburban home.

props.synopsis: The results are in — Trent Dalton's Boy Swallows Universe has won Radio National's inaugural Top 100 Books of the 21st Century.

title.children: Boy Swallows Universe voted our favourite read of the century

image.altText: Two men on a podium, wearing head coverings and caps, raise their fists.

props.synopsis: A year after Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto won the election, the families of Indonesians arrested in recent protests are expressing dissatisfaction with his leadership.

title.children: In Indonesia, Prabowo's first year in power marked by arrests and protests

image.altText: A man having his eyes washed

props.synopsis: Two Victoria Police officers were hospitalised after violent clashes, while protesters were also arrested following scuffles in Canberra.

title.children: Tensions erupt in Melbourne as immigration rallies held across Australia

image.altText: A starry sky and a small meteor over a dark beach.

props.synopsis: This week is a great time to find somewhere dark and look up with the Orionid meteor shower gracing southern skies. Here's everything you need to know about this annual sky show.

title.children: The Orionid meteor shower peaks tomorrow morning. Here's how to see it

image.altText: Two women walk through university grounds in graduation robes

props.synopsis: A 20 per cent reduction on HECS debt is a welcomed relief for some 3 million Australians with a student loan. But those who paid their HECS early or are yet to rack up a debt will miss out on the support.

title.children: 'Do I pay it off? Do I not?': Young Australians' HECS debt dilemma

image.altText: Raúl Fernández celebrates on the podium after winning Australian MotoGP.

props.synopsis: Raúl Fernández breaks through for his first MotoGP win, but Australian Jack Miller's race ends in agony at Phillip Island.

title.children: Spaniard ends drought by winning Aussie MotoGP as Miller fails to finish

image.altText: Peter ToRot illustration.

props.synopsis: Peter ToRot, a Papua New Guinea man killed in prison in 1945 for standing up for monogamous marriage at a time when polygamy was practised has been canonised a saint.

title.children: Pope Leo XIV canonises Papua New Guinea's first Catholic saint

image.altText: A close up of Prince Andrew looking over his shoulder and wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: With the swirl of news around Prince Andrew this week, something had to be done; the question was whether he would do it himself or if his brother would be forced to show him the door.

title.children: Prince Andrew's downfall may have been orchestrated by Prince William

image.altText: Mitck Marsh struck in the head by a rising delivery in ODI against India.

props.synopsis: Surviving a series of rain delays in Perth, Australia records a seven-wicket win over India in the first of three men's ODI matches.

title.children: Australia ends Perth 'hoodoo' with win over India in rain-shortened ODI

image.altText: clear bags of white substances with blue NSW police logo on the bags

props.synopsis: Highway patrol stopped the black luxury SUV on a major New South Wales highway for a random drug and alcohol test on Friday afternoon.

title.children: Highway patrol find $6 million drug haul in NSW vehicle stop

image.altText: Times Square packed with large crowds of protesters, shot fom above to show the square's billboard signs and red steps

props.synopsis: Organisers say the rallies reflect frustration over the Trump administration's prosecutions of the president's perceived enemies, immigration raids and the sending of troops into US cities.

title.children: 'No Kings' protests gather across the US against Trump's leadership

image.altText: A man in military uniform, aiming a weapon, seen from side on.

props.synopsis: Blasted into the bedrock, deep below the streets of Helsinki, these massive bunkers are currently used for recreation. Their primary function, however, is much more sinister: preparing for a Russian invasion.

title.children: Finland has a message for Vladimir Putin: We're ready

image.altText: a black object on a dusty red dirt road

props.synopsis: Suspected space debris is believed to have crashed near a WA mine site, with the Australian Transport Safety Bureau confirming the object was not from a commercial aircraft.

title.children: Possible space 'rocket tank' found in WA, triggering police response

image.altText: Claire Jackson takes a selfie with son Brodie

props.synopsis: After a traumatic birth, followed by mental and physical health challenges, Claire was "one and done". But divorce made her think twice about her decision.

title.children: How Claire's decision to be 'one and done' was rocked by divorce

image.altText: Headshot of Barnaby Joyce.

props.synopsis: Announcing he would not re-contest his seat of New England for the Nationals, Barnaby Joyce cited an irreparable breakdown with his party leader David Littleproud. Mr Littleproud says he still wants Mr Joyce to stay.

title.children: Nationals leader wants Joyce to 'stay', amid rumour of One Nation defection

image.altText: Matthew Hauser crossed finish line at world championship finals in Wollongong.

props.synopsis: Australia's Matthew Hauser finishes on top of the men's World Triathlon Championship Series standings following his victory on home soil.

title.children: Australia's Matthew Hauser wins world triathlon title in Wollongong final

image.altText: A older well dressed couple smile and pose for camera outside an old house.

props.synopsis: Classical musicians Richard and Suzy Miller count their circa-1832 home as one of their greatest creative achievements as they prepare to leave it for someone else to love.

title.children: 'Someone else's turn now': Iconic house for sale for only second time in 193-year history

image.altText: a man pulls a snake from its tail

props.synopsis: A passenger in a car has the fright of his life when a tiger snake slithers across his feet during a drive on the NSW far south coast.

title.children: 'Hell of a fright': Snake slithers over man's foot on drive to the shops

image.altText: A golf course with lots of trees along the side and a city in the background

props.synopsis: As the Malinauskas government proceeds with its $50 million North Adelaide golf course upgrade, some Kaurna elders are grappling with the prospect that the redevelopment could uncover Aboriginal remains.

title.children: Future LIV Golf site decision sparks mixed reaction from Kaurna community

image.altText: Ange Postecolgou puts his head down.

props.synopsis: Ange Postecolgou was on a hiding to nothing at Nottingham Forest, his sacking the result of terrible recruitment and a knee-jerk appointment.

title.children: How a Brian Clough quote sums up Ange's mistake at Forest

image.altText: Graphic of an elderly woman walking towards a door with a medical carer by her side and the word 'exit' above the door

props.synopsis: For many, voluntary assisted dying has come to symbolise control over how life ends. Yet dying well isn't just about those final hours. That's where a deathwalker like Zenith can help.

title.children: Deathwalkers and voluntary assisted dying are changing end-of-life care

image.altText: An older woman wearing a blue vest sits at a table counting ballot papers.

props.synopsis: Bruce Reynolds has held onto the title of City of Perth Lord Mayor, while early figures from WA's local government elections show voter turnout is below what authorities hoped for.

title.children: Acting Perth lord mayor wins job as local government election counting continues

image.altText: A black and white photograph of the collapsed West Gate Bridge with a fire burning in the wreckage.

props.synopsis: The people impacted by Australia's worst industrial disaster are at the centre of West Gate by Dennis McIntosh, one of seven new Australian plays coming to Melbourne Theatre Company in 2026.

title.children: In 1970, West Gate Bridge collapsed, killing 35. It's the basis for a new play

image.altText: A group of Aboriginal children with white paint, red clothing, with an adult man who is also wearing a hat, dancing together.

props.synopsis: Traditional owners of the remote NT Aboriginal community of Wadeye say the community has been brought "together as one family" at this year's Yidiyi cultural festival.

title.children: Cultural festival brings Aboriginal community together after conflict

image.altText: solar panels on an outback farm

props.synopsis: Australia's renewable energy push has resulted in a surge in household solar power. But what does that mean for private solar farms?

title.children: How cheap, widespread power from the sun could overshadow solar farms
